moves.1. e4 e6: This is the French Defence. I used to play it a lot, so I know what is coming.
moves.2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4: This is something different than the closed positions arising from moves like 3...Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e5 Nd7 6. Bxe7 Qxe7 etc.
moves.4... Nd7 5. Nf3: I can also play 5. Bd3 which can lead to the same kind of positions than in this game.
moves.5... Ngf6 6. Nxf6+: I practice I have to exchange the knights anyway. For example, 6. Bd3 Nxe4 7. Bxe4 Nf6 8. Bd3 etc.
moves.6... Nxf6 7. Bd3: There are other moves here that I could play, such as Bg5, c3, Be3, Bc4 etc. The one that I selected takes the e4-square and potentially targets h7.
moves.7... c5: This is logical. Black challenges the central control by attacking d4.
moves.8. O-O: I could take on c5, but instead, I move the king to a safer place. There is a little tactical trick that makes this possible, although d4 is threatened.
moves.9. Nxd4: And I take back! 9...Qxd4 would be followed by 10. Bb5+ winning the queen.
moves.9... Bc5: So Black develops a piece with tempo.
moves.10... Qc7: Now I cannot pin the f6-knight.
moves.11. Bg5: I still move the bishop to g5, because other active squares are covered by Black pieces. I also have the option to break Black's kingside pawn structure.
moves.11... O-O 12. Qe2: Breaking the pawn structure here is probably not worth losing the bishop pair.
moves.12... b6: Preparing to bring the bishop to b7.
moves.13. Ne5: This is a good square for the knight.
moves.13... Bb7 14. Rad1: The rook takes the open file.
moves.14... Nd5: I do not like this move. Bringing a rook to oppose mine on the d-file would be better, I think.
moves.15... Nb4: This seems like a good move, but it is not.
moves.16. Bxh7+: Surprise! Black steps into a trap.
moves.18. Bf6: Making it more spectacular than necessary. 18. Qh5+ Kg8 19. Bf6 also works.
moves.18... gxf6: If Black does not take, White delivers checkmate anyway. For example, 18...Kg8 19. Qg4 g6 20. Qxg6!! fxg6 21. Rg7+ Kh8 22. Ng6#
moves.19. Qh5+: Not the fastest way to win. 19. Rxf7+ Rxf7 20. Qh5+ Kg8 21. Qxf7+ Kh8 22. Ng6#
moves.20. Ng4: This is a bad move which allows Black to defend a bit longer. Instead, 20. Nxf7 wins: 20...Bxf2 21. Rxf2 Kg7 22. Qh6+ Kg8 23. Qh8# or 20...Rxf7 21. Qxf7+ Kh8 22. Qh7#
moves.20... Qxd7: This returns the favor. Instead, 21...Be7 22. Rxe8 Qc5 23. Nxf6+ Kg7 24. Rxb7 Qxh5 25. Nxh5+ etc. and there is no checkmate, although White is two pawns up and probably winning.
